Award.AwardTitle: Examining the Role of the Endomebrane in Transcription Factor Movement

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT
In order for organisms to develop and function properly, cells within the organism must be able to communicate with each other. In plants, communication can occur through specialized intercellular channels called plasmodesmata. Nearly all cells in the plant are connected through plasmodesmata, which allow for the direct exchange of proteins between cells. This means that proteins made by one cell can travel into the neighboring cell and influence the behavior and/or developmental fate of the neighbor. An important question in cell signaling is how this type of protein movement is regulated. Recently the primary investigator identified a protein that she has called SIEL (for SHORT-ROOT INTERACTING EMBRYONIC LETHAL) that promotes the movement of a plant-encoded transcription factor called SHORT-ROOT (SHR) between cells. Movement of SHR is required for the proper formation and growth of the plant root and therefore overall growth of the plant. In addition to SHR, SIEL also interacts with several other mobile transcription factors that are important for plant growth. It is likely that SIEL promotes the movement of other key proteins in plant growth as mutations that cause SIEL not to be produced result in death of the plant early in embryo development. Current data suggest that SIEL acts as an intracellular shuttle that promotes plasmodesmata-dependent movement of proteins through associations with intercellular membranes (specifically endosomes) and the microtubule cytoskeleton. The goal of this project is to determine how SIEL functions in the cell-to-cell transport of proteins during plant development. This research has obvious relevance to plant development and cell biology. In addition, as plant viruses are thought to exploit endogenous plant pathways for intercellular movement, there is relevance to plant disease resistance and agriculture where viral infections can decimate crop yields.

BROADER IMPACTS
The primary investigator runs a laboratory in which research participation by students at all levels is highly encouraged. She has hosted students from the local middle schools and high schools and has both high school and undergraduate students actively working in her laboratory on a daily basis. In addition she has actively engaged with local teachers and a Penn education major to develop laboratory exercises that can be performed with materials inexpensively and readily available online or in local grocery or gardening stores. These laboratory exercises meet Pennsylvania standards and benchmarks for science education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To control development and metabolism, multicellular organisms must coordinate and maintain communication between cells. In plants, much of this signaling occurs via the intercellular transport of transcription factors. Transcription factors made by one cell can travel into the neighboring cell, enter the nucleus, bind DNA and initiate changes in transcription. Examination of many mobile proteins in plants has shown that most (if not all) move via plasmodesmata (PD; plasma membrane lined channels that extend between cells). However, what remains unclear is how proteins get to PD and how access is controlled. Using the mobile protein, SHORT-ROOT (SHR) as a model for understanding protein movement in plants, we identified unconventional roles for the endomembrane and the cytoskeleton in SHR movement. We suggest that within the cell, soluble cytoplasmically localized proteins, like SHR can interact with endosomes. Via interaction with endosmes SHR is able to assemble into a complex capable of  transport between cells. Within this context, the cytoskeleton stabilizes the interaction between SHR and the endomembrane, essentially creating a stable platform the modification of SHR into a movement competent form.

In addition to examining the cell biology of SHR movement we also investigated the consequences of movement to plant development. SHR is a member of the conserved group of GRAS family transcription factors. Homologs of the SHR protein have been found in nearly all sequenced plant genomes. Using severel species of economically and agriculturally important plants (e.g rice and maize) I we showed that the capacity for SHR to move is conserved. Interestingly in maize nd rice SHR movement plays important roles in both the patterning of the root and the control of intervascular spacing in leaves that is indicative of Kranz anatomy. This funding led to over nine publications.

Three post-docs and one graduate student were supported by this grant. All were active members of the laboratory, participating both in internal seminar series, educational programs and community outreach. Four undergraduate students, were funded also funded by this grant. In addition, funding from this grant allowed undergraduate students from the department of education to develop laboratory skills (mentored by members of the host laboratory) relevant to teaching middle school and high school level biology.
